1.name: Design for people's needs
1.description: Put the needs of Californians first in everything you do. Make your guiding question, “What does someone need to do?”
1.example: The per page feedback component makes it easy to learn about the needs of your audience.

2.name: Do the hard work to make it simple and elegant
2.description: Government services often put the burden on people to understand and navigate services and policies. Break down these barriers for them to create simple, understandable services.
2.example: The step list component takes complicated processes and makes their steps transparent.

3.name: Prioritize accessibility
3.description: Make your services accessible for all Californians. Think about people who have been traditionally excluded, like people who use screen readers or reside in low bandwidth regions.
3.example: Our visual design style guide includes direction on how to create accessible design. All design system components are WCAG 2.1 compliant.

4.name: Be concise
4.description: Things are easy to use when they’re simple. Ask yourself, “Does this word, image, or functionality help people do what they need to do?”
4.example: Our content design guidelines provide actionable tips for writing in plain language. This makes information to the point and easy to read.

5.name: Design with data
5.description: Use research and analytics to understand how people use your services and products. This keeps us focused on their needs, not preconceived solutions.
5.example: Design System components work seamlessly with Google Analytics. This gathers information about the people who use your services and their needs.

6.name: Iterate, then iterate again
6.description: Services and products are never finished. Rigorously test and refine your work to make sure it’s robust and useful.
6.example: We continuously look at data and improve Design System components. Our Alpha, Beta, and Production labels show what development track each component is in.

7.name: Be consistent, but not uniform
7.description: Use the component, content, and visual guidelines. This creates a shared, consistent experience across state departments.
7.example: The statewide header is a default component of the Design System. This helps people know they are on a CA.gov website.

8.name: Optimize performance
8.description: Not every Californian has a high-end device. When you build services and products, think about people on a range of devices and internet speeds.
8.example: Websites built with the design system have a Lighthouse performance score X% higher than the average CA.gov website.

9.name: Make things open
9.description: As part of our commitment to transparency and collaboration, our default state is to share. Our Design System work is open to the public.
9.example: All of the Design System code is open source and hosted on Github. This means anyone can see how it's built, suggest improvements, or adapt it for their own purposes.
